Title: Health Comms Assessment
Author: Yusuf Atef
Public Summary: Between 8 and 11 April, a communications assessment was conducted in Kamwenge District to determine the communication needs and strategies necessary to support health projects within Rwamwanja refugee settlement and the district at large. This project aims to make evidence-informed recommendations on the type of communication activities and materials to be used in creating awareness and promoting positive and healthy behavior among the Congolese refugees and the host communities within Kamwenge District.
Subject: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, Family planning

All the three health centres have completed the implementation of the activities at the outreach posts and are currently compiling the data.

Title: Site Visit at Rwenzori Diocese Headquarters Fort Portal
Author: Stephen Wandera
Public Summary:
Held PQA meetings and field monitoring visits 20th to 22nd March 2013 in Kabarole and Bundibugyo Districts. The areas of focus included Program Management, Effectiveness and Efficiency of Monitoring and Reporting, Supply Management, Implementation Progress and End User Feedback.
Observations included inadequate Involvement of District Officials in the program, funds requested by the partner were reportedly cut without consultation, communication on supplies was inadequate, monitoring and review plans were absent and more follow ups of community interventions were needed.
Subject: Education and training in water supply and sanitation, Early childhood education, Social/ welfare services, Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, Education facilities and training, Education policy and administrative management, Personnel development for population and reproductive health

Title: Koch Kalang
Author: Rabbin Mike Drabe
Public Summary: Before UNICEF intervention, water and sanitation provision in Nwoya schools was non-existent or in an appalling state. UNICEF/District programmes have since put in hardware that has significantly improved the coverage of latrines, drinking and washing water. More investment has been made in hygiene education. Another major effort to monitor and re-plan district wide, and without more investment in water and sanitation for the surrounding communities, the sustainability of the hardware and the consolidation of behaviour change may be lost.
Subject: Education and training in water supply and sanitation

Title: Site Visit at PATIRA
Author: Rabbin Mike Drabe
Public Summary: UNICEF supported the district of Nwoya to conduct Go Back to school campaign at the beginning of the term. It is expected that this will encourage children of school going age to enrolled, stay in school and complete the primary education cycle. The parents in Nwoya district have the tendency of keeping the children at home to support the parents in cultivation. The support provided by UNICEF will service to sensitize the community about these negative cultural practices has a positive effect
Subject: Education facilities and training, Primary education

Title: Site Visit at Kalongo
Author: Sammy G. Poro
Public Summary:
In UNICEF the Operations and Programme Coordination sections coordinate the assurance activities. TOs make informed decisions about the PQA visits by using the PSIM quarterly PQA schedule, based on cumulative activity implemented and liquidated DCTs.Implementing partners participate in PQA visits. IPs includes PTCs, FBOs, NGOs, GoU institutions, Central Ministries and DLG; they are engaged in results-focused end-user monitoring of activities implemented.
Programme coordination monitors the completion rate of all recommendations generated from the various programmatic assurance exercises
Subject: Primary education

Title: Site Visit at Enik ECD centre
Author: Hajara Ndayidde
Public Summary: Enik ECD centre in Kaabong- has a daily routine pinned up in the classroom. Some of the parts are no implemented. Caregivers had no lesson plans and the learning framework for ECD. 6 out of the 7 caregivers are trained.
Subject: Early childhood education

Title: Meeting with the District planner
Location: SNV - CEP Review Meeting: District Council Hall
Author: Harriet Akullu
Public Summary: Over 2,700 births had been notified during the Family Health Days of October and July rounds. From the mobili VRS, the district planner had entered data for only 63 children. This mission sought to determine and address the bottle necks preventing the registration of tese birth nortified.
Subject: Human rights

Title: Site Visit at Arua referal Hospital bordroom
Author: Jacob Opiyo
Public Summary: Arua district successfully completed its first round of family health days (FHDs) implementation which saw a large number of children and mothers being reached with the services. More than 42,000 children’s births were registered while about 50,000 and 70,000 children were given Vitamin A and deworming respectively among other services. The district held a meeting to review the performance of the past round of implementation and to plan for the April 2013 FHDs round. A total of 515 places of worship have been identified as out reaches centres for the April 2013 round
Subject: Infectious disease control

Title: Site Visit at Ogom Telela
Author: Sammy G. Poro
Public Summary:
In UNICEF Uganda when an Implementing Partner receives cash, the Operations and Programme Coordination sections coordinate the assurance activities and share the results. TOs make informed decisions about the PQA visits that should be included in quarterly travel plans by using the PSIM quarterly PQA schedule, based on cumulative liquidated DCTs.
Ideally a PQA visit is arranged when: activity is implemented,and funds disbursed are accounted for/liquidated and when the last PQA is not less than 12 months ago. IPs are invited to participate in PQA visits.
Subject: Primary education

Title: Site Visit at Anaka Town Council
Author: Rabbin Mike Drabe
Public Summary: UNICEF has supported Nwoya district to carry out Family Health Days at 148 places of worship in Nwoya district. The trends show that there is progressive improvement in the uptake of Immunization, birth registration, ANC attendance, HIV testing by the community from June 2012 to date. The challenge of Human resource and inadequate social mobilization need to be address in the month of April 2013
Subject: Infectious disease control

Title: Site Visit at Rwamwanja refugee camp
Author: Dheepa Pandian
Public Summary: Compiled and documented the impact of United Nations support in Rwamwanja refugee camp a home for over 35,000 refugees from DRC who have fled the recent fighting in DRC. Also Documented the use of the new UNICEF innovative mobile phone based programme known as the Rapid Family Tracing and reunification (RapidFTR). Worked with a videographer and photographer and videos and images have been uploaded on the country office website for further visibility of the impact of UNICEF Uganda programmes on beneficiaries.
Subject: Social/ welfare services

Title: Site Visit at Aber Youth Centre, Oyam South
Author: Joy Birabwa
Public Summary: On the last day of the visit, we went through Aber Youth center to attend a youth discussion. The close to thirty youth shared their learning experiences revolving around the 08 days that An, a student from the art center had spent with them. Some of the girls explained why it has been possible for them to come to the youth centre often, how and what they have gained.
Subject: Basic life skills for youth and adults

Title: Site Visit at Kigoyera
Author: Harriet Akullu

Title: Site Visit at Bundingoma COU
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: FHD implementation had not yet started when I arrived at Bundingoma COU around 10.40 a.m. on Sunday 3/3/2013. The Church leaders had instructed the health workers not to start FHD services until after prayers. All the human resources needed were deployed at the POW. However, not all supplies and logistics were available at the site and there was low turn up of clients. There is need to avail all supplies and logistics for FHD, discuss with Church leaders to be flexible about time of starting FHD, and the district leaderships to improve on mobilisation strategies.
Subject: Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS

Title: Site Visit at Bususu Roman Catholic Church
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: At Bususu Catholic Church, FHD implementation was started around 9.30 a.m. and continued uninterrupted. All human resources were deployed at the POW. Some supplies and logistics were lacking at the site. There was also low turn up of clients. There is need to provide all supplies and logistics and carry out intensive social mobilisation for better FHD performance.
Subject: Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS

Title: Site Visit at Busunga Catholic Church
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: At Busunga Catholic Church, FHD was going on well except 1 health worker and the FBO leader were missing. This caused gap in birth registration and other service provision. Some supplies and logistics were lacking at the site.  Total of 12 children were already immunised and 22 adults had their B.P taken at the time of my arrival to monitor the program. In the forthcoming FHD sessions, there is need to have all human resources, supplies and logistics at the POW.
Subject: Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS

Title: Site Visit at Nyankonda Catholic Church
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: Nyankonda Catholic Church FHD implementation had similar findings as other sites – late starting, some supplies lacking, and low turn up of clients. Need for DHO, DHT and other players to ensure all supplies are provided for the exercise and mobilisation carried out well.
Subject: Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS

Title: Site Visit at Bunyagule Catholic Church
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: The lack of supplies, low turn up of clients and delay in starting FHD implementation were the major issues at Bunyagule Catholic Church. The DHO and DHT to ensure all supplies and logistics are delivered to the POWs and mobilisation is carried out using different strategies.
Subject: Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS

Title: Site Visit at Galilaya COU
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: At around 16.15 hours, 20 children had been immunised and 23 females had their B.P taken. Only 2 health workers were at Galilaya COU for FHD. VHT was absent, while the Church leader was present but not handling birth registration. Due to staff shortage, birth registration, MUAC screening, and other services were not being provided. The general turn up of the clients was also poor having been affected by reliance only on radio program. DHO to ensure all the necessary staff are deployed at POWs in the next FHD rounds, and other channels of communication explored.
Subject: Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS

Title: Site Visit at Ngai Youth Centre

Public Summary: Ngai Youth centre has not been active since the withdrawal of ASB. However, it is hoped that with the technicalities sorted out and the computers working now, Ngai Youth centre will become more active.

Title: Site Visit at Monitoring ECD orientation training for DIS, DHI, FBOs, DPOs EO on Licensing and Registration of ECD centres
Location: Monitoring ECD orientation training for DIS, DHI, FBOs, DPOs EO on Licensing and Registration of ECD centres
Author: Sammy G. Poro
Public Summary: UNICEF is supporting  MoES in the implementation of ECD programme.    Registration of ECD centres and Training Caregivers & Centre Management Committees are undertakings  that is being monitored and reported on by  MoES.  UNICEF has taken up this with the FBOs and other partners, DLG, BRAC, CSCD, and the PTCs to support the process for quality results. Gulu CPTC conducted an orientation with MoES TIET department for the 12 DLG of Gulu, Amuru, Nwoya, Kitgum, Lamwo, Pader, Agago, Nebbi, Zombo, Arua, Oyam and Buliisa on licensing and  Registration of ECD centres at TAKS centre in Gulu
Subject: Early childhood education

Title: Site Visit at Monitoring Program implementation
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: Rubirizi had an outstanding amount of Shs.9, 174,000 which was used for district OVC mapping and registration. Accountability to be submitted to UNICEF as soon as possible to avoid getting beyond 6 months. OVC data cleaning and analysis was still on-going, the results yet to be shared. Participated in district Technical, Planning and Coordination (TPC) meeting in which I highlighted areas where UNICEF has been supporting Rubirizi district
Subject: Water resources policy and administrative management, Water resources protection, Water supply and sanitation - large systems, Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, Basic nutrition, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, Family planning, STD control including HIV/AIDS, Primary education, Social/ welfare services

Title: Ezuku P/S
Location: Dissemination of Arua Education Ordinance at Ezuku P/S
Author: Jacob Opiyo
Public Summary: Arua district local embarked on the dissemination of the education ordinance of 2008 and the early childhood development policy. The district developed the ordinance through consultation of various stakeholders and was finally passed by the district council in 2008. The ordinance is aimed at improving the education standards in the district through addressing some of the key factors that affects performance of pupils in schools.
Subject: Education policy and administrative management, Early childhood education

Title: Site Visit at Lacor P.7 School
Author: Joy Birabwa
Public Summary:
Lacor Primary school has computers and wireless internet set up by BOSCO Uganda. In Lacor Primary school, I met with the Head Teacher, Mr. Anywar who introduced me to Teacher Irene Amito, the teacher for Primary Four. She got together about 15 pupils and the numbers increased as the lesson went on.  The lessons reviewed were English and Social Studies.
In the same forum, the sub country Councillor for Education watched the videos.
Subject: Educational research

Title: Site Visit at District Headquarters
Author: Jackson Ojera Abusu
Public Summary: Held meetings with DIT. Guided DEO/DIS to use door to door strategy in GBS campaign and not just meeting stakeholders at the sub-county level. Discussed concept paper with heads and staffs of four sectors with conclusion that they need to review and select few priorities out of priorities. Discussed with WASH team CDC Atlanta’s plan to intervene in control of continued outbreak of Typhoid in Kasese. The team wishes to partner with a local NGO that can sustain the interventions even when CDC winds up the project.
Subject: Water resources policy and administrative management, Water supply and sanitation - large systems, Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, Infectious disease control, Reproductive health care, STD control including HIV/AIDS, Primary education
